sense.name: convey, show, state in some form
sense.commentary: Includes: EXPRESS EMOTION, EXPRESS FEELINGS, EXPRESS JOY, EXPRESS MIRTH
sense.examples: Dogs express happiness through wagging their tails. I expressed my opinion about the new housing project at last night's meeting. The children could only express the answer in Fahrenheit, not in Centigrade. Picasso's Guernica vividly expresses the horrors of war.

sense.name: press out physically
sense.examples: Italians express coffee rather than filter it.

sense.name: to mail or post something via a rapid method
sense.examples: Can you express these packages overnight to corporate headquarters?
